README

======================================================= Warning — you probably don't want this repository unless you're developing the http://pi.gate.ac.uk/ site itself.

For source code for projects on that site, links to our software downloads and the like, see https://github.com/hamishcunningham/pi-tronics =======================================================

Contents

  • 1. The basics
  • 2. New posts, new pages
  • 3. Checking in etc.
  • 4. Relative links
  • 5. Misc

1. The basics

How to work with these sources:

  • send your github ID to hamish and get authorised
  • install git, java and pelican
  • fire up a shell and:

git clone git@github.com:hamishcunningham/pi-gate.git
cd pi-gate
make html
make serve
Hey presto you should have the site running on http://localhost:8000

You can then edit content/... to your heart's content; when you want to regen the on-line version just do "make html" again.

Note that the source code examples live in another repo:

git clone git@github.com:hamishcunningham/pi-tronics.git

2. New posts, new pages

The easy way to make a new post is to choose a title (e.g. "martians-landing") and do

 TITLE=martians-landing make post
Then follow the instructions. The longer story is that new posts should be in the form content/YYYY-MM-DD-the-title.html (you can use GATEwiki syntax — .yam — or markdown or other Pelican-friendly formats if you like). For each new post also add

  • content/images/articles/the-title.jpg — a characteristic image for the post
  • content/images/articles/thumbs/the-title.jpg — a 75x75 thumbnail of the image

Tip: you can generate the latter from the former with: 

 convert -thumbnail 75 the-title.jpg thumbs/the-title.jpg
TODO is this unnesc now, at least for "normal" pages? To add a new page (as opposed to a new post) add to the STANDARD_PAGES list in the Makefile (or the NO_META_PAGES if you want to avoid insertion of metadata in the new page, probably because it is a bare HTML with meta tags already present).

3. Checking in etc.

When you want to share your changes:

git commit -vam "what I just did"
git push
The latest published version is at http://pi.gate.ac.uk/

The latest draft is at http://tinyurl.com/pimo-draft (u: pimo p: learn)

4. Relative links

Relative links between pages, images etc. should just work within the content tree (no need to use Pelican's |filename| syntax). [note: there used to be an exception for links that reference another page and an anchor (e.g. basics.html#parent-alarm), which Pelican doesn't like; this is now fixed by enpelicanise.sh and the finalise Makefile target.]

5. Misc
